oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An Outbreak of sarcocytosis in dairy cattle
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Carrigan, M. J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: environment
cattle disease
parasite
sporozoan
canine disease
cattle infection
S. cruzi
dog
sarcocystosis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sixteen of 32 Friesian calves, 8 to 10 weeks old, died over 4 weeks. The calves were housed in pens previously used by dogs. Clinical signs included anorexia, pale mucous membranes, rapid weight loss, coughing and palpably enlarged superficial lymph nodes. At necropsy, calves were emaciated and had generalised enlargement of lymph nodes, pale mottling of skeletal muscles, excess peritoneal, thoracic and pericardial fluid and subpleural and subepicardial haemorrhages. Histologically there was a lymphadenitis, myositis, myocarditis, glomerulonephritis, interstitial pneumonia and encephalitis. Schizonts of a sporozoan parasite, presumably Sarcocystis cruzi were found in the endothelial cells of blood vessels in many organs.
